intro: Chionanthus ramiflorus, commonly known as the fringed gentian, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its showy, white or pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and has opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are clustered in terminal racemes and are often surrounded by bracts that resemble petals. The genus Chionanthus is part of the Oleaceae family, which includes other flowering plants like lilacs and forsythia.
